video.title_en: Discovery of Magnetism | First PUC | William Gilbert

summary.text_en: William Gilbert, royal physician, published 'De Magnete', a landmark work that marks the birth of experimental science. Based on 17 years of hundreds of rigorous experiments, Gilbert (1) **was the first to clearly distinguish 'electricity' (from rubbing amber) from 'magnetism' (from lodestone)**, and (2) proved that a compass points north *because the Earth itself is one giant magnet*, which he demonstrated using a model Earth (a 'Terrella').
key_points_en: Proved the 'Earth is a giant magnet'
First to clearly distinguish 'static electricity' from 'magnetism'
Coined the word 'Electricity' (from *elektron*, Greek for amber)

story.text_en: Before Gilbert, electricity and magnetism were lumped together as a mystical 'attraction'. Gilbert insisted on *experiment*. He fashioned a spherical lodestone (a 'Terrella', or 'little Earth') and moved a tiny compass needle over its surface. He found the needle lay flat at the 'equator' but pointed straight down at the 'poles'. This perfectly matched the 'magnetic dip' observed by sailors. He thus made the bold conclusion: the Earth itself *is* a giant magnet, and compasses point north because they are aligning with the Earth's own magnetic field.

fun_facts.text_en: Gilbert was the first person to coin the New Latin word 'electricus' (from *elektron*, the Greek word for 'amber') to describe static attraction. The English word 'Electricity' comes from this.
Galileo (`galileo_motion_1638`) deeply admired 'De Magnete' and called Gilbert the 'first true experimental scientist'.
To distinguish electricity from magnetism, Gilbert invented the 'versorium', a pivoting metal needle that was the first electroscope, a sensitive detector of static electric charge.

simple_explanation.text_en:
In 1600, people thought magnets and rubbed amber (static) were the same 'magic'. Gilbert was the first to say, 'No, let's experiment.'
1. He proved 'electricity' attracts *everything* (feathers, water, metal), while 'magnetism' *only* attracts iron.
2. He proved 'electricity' can be blocked (by moisture), while 'magnetism' goes right through things.
3. Most importantly, he built a 'mini-Earth' magnet and proved that compasses work *not* because the North Star is 'pulling' them, but because the *Earth itself* is one giant magnet.

applications.text_en: His theory (Earth as a magnet) provided the first scientific explanation for *why* a compass works, crucial for navigation and surveying.

applications.text_en: De Magnete was the first modern scientific text based entirely on 'systematic experiment' rather than 'philosophical speculation', paving the way for Galileo (`galileo_motion_1638`).

applications.title: ç”µå­¦ (Electricity)
applications.text_en: By separating and naming 'electricity' from magnetism, he laid the conceptual groundwork for electricity (`guericke_static_generator_1663`) to become its own science 150 years later.

impact.text_en: De Magnete is one of the first true works of the Scientific Revolution. It marks the decisive shift away from Aristotelian speculation (`aristotle_elements_BC350`) and toward Galilean experimentalism. Gilbert replaced reliance on 'ancient authority' with hundreds of repeatable 'experiments'. He also introduced the revolutionary idea of the Earth's magnetism, which in turn lent support to the Copernican model (`copernicus_heliocentrism_1543`), as Kepler would later try to use magnetism to explain planetary orbits.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Ancient Greeks & Chinese (for their early observations of lodestone and amber)

influenced.contribution_en: Galileo (whose 'experimental method' was deeply inspired by Gilbert)
Kepler (his attempt to explain planetary orbits with 'magnetic forces' was directly inspired by Gilbert's 'Earth-magnet')
Otto von Guericke (his 'electrostatic generator' was the direct successor to Gilbert's work on electricity)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: William Gilbert is the 'father of experimental physics'. He separated electricity from magnetism and proved the Earth itself is a giant magnet.

quiz.question_en: What were the two most important conclusions from William Gilbert's 'De Magnete' (1600)?
options_en: Electricity and Magnetism are the same thing; the Earth is the center of the universe
Electricity and Magnetism are *different* forces; the Earth *itself* is a giant magnet
Electricity creates Magnetism; the Earth orbits the Sun
Magnetism creates Electricity; the Earth is hollow
quiz.explanation_en: Gilbert's great contribution was using experiments to prove that 'electricity' (from amber) and 'magnetism' (from lodestone) were two separate phenomena, and that a compass works by aligning with the magnetic field of the Earth itself.
